make an new class extending thread.

In it’s run method…

public void run() { while(true) try{ Sleep(50000); putFunctionToRestartServerHere(); }catch(Exception e) {} } }
Sorry for mess code, can’t use tab button.

Then, when you’re server starts up, make a new instance of that class and call it’s start() function.

item.title: Antilag
item.dc:creator: @hellou hellou
item.description:
@hellou wrote:

[code]// This resets server every 30 mins to stop lag - xerozcheez
import java.io.*;

public class antilag
{

public int ResetTimer = 300;

public void resetserver()
{
misc.println(“RESETING SERVER!!!”);
misc.println(“Saving all games…”);
PlayerHandler.kickAllPlayers = true;
misc.println(“GAME SUCCESSFULLY SAVED FOR ALL PLAYERS”);
ResetTimer = 0;
closeListener();
runserver();
}
public void process()
{
ResetTimer += 300;
if(ResetTimer >= 300)
{
resetserver();
}
}

public void runserver()
{
try
{
String run = “runserver.bat”;
String xstr = “./”+run;
Runtime.getRuntime().exec(xstr);
}
catch (IOException ioe)
{
ioe.printStackTrace();
}
}

public void closeListener()
{
try {
server.shutdownClientHandler = true;
if(server.clientListener != null) server.clientListener.close();
server.clientListener = null;
}
catch(java.lang.Exception __ex)
{
__ex.printStackTrace();
}
}
}[/code]
